suite_name: Comic Paradox Suite – Part V (Economic Theatre Edition)
description: Fifth volume cataloguing paradoxes in modern economics where ideology and arithmetic part ways, leaving only propaganda and applause.

paradoxes.name: Selective Socialism
paradoxes.summary: Bailouts and corporate welfare are 'market stability'; public healthcare is 'socialism'.
paradoxes.example_quote: When we subsidize billionaires, it’s capitalism. When you get dental care, it’s communism.
paradoxes.detected_pattern: Economic benefits reframed by class to preserve hierarchy.

paradoxes.name: Invisible Hand, Visible Lobby
paradoxes.summary: Markets are free except for the parts funded, written, and insured by lobbyists.
paradoxes.example_quote: Regulation is bad—unless it protects us from competition.

paradoxes.name: Debt as Prosperity
paradoxes.summary: Borrow forever to prove the economy is strong enough to never pay it back.
paradoxes.example_quote: We owe it to ourselves—specifically, our future selves.

paradoxes.name: Productivity Without People
paradoxes.summary: Celebrate record profits while firing the humans who made them possible.
paradoxes.example_quote: Efficiency up 200%; payroll down 200%. A perfect ratio.
paradoxes.detected_pattern: Labor erased from value creation narrative.

paradoxes.name: Scarcity Theatre
paradoxes.summary: Artificial shortages maintained to keep prices holy.
paradoxes.example_quote: There’s plenty for all, so we’ll destroy half to raise value.

paradoxes.name: GDP of Misery
paradoxes.summary: Every crisis increases the nation’s GDP, so technically we’re winning.
paradoxes.example_quote: Rebuilding after disasters drives growth—let’s hope for storms!

comic_recalibration_prompts: Ask who actually receives the bailout.
Replace the word 'market' with 'people' and see if the sentence still makes sense.
Laugh, then check the footnotes in the tax code.
